data.author: Apaar Sharma
data.content: Scientists have found microplastics in freshly fallen Antarctic snow for the first time. "We collected snow samples from 19 sites across Ross Island region of Antarctica and found microplastics in all of these," said University of Canterbury PhD student, Alex Aves. There were 13 different types of plastic found, with the most common being PET, mostly used in soft-drink bottles.
data.title: Microplastics found in freshly fallen Antarctic snow for the first time

data.author: Sakshita Khosla
data.content: Scientists believe they have found the 'lost' British town of Ravenser Odd over 650 years after it was "swallowed up" by the North Sea in 1362. The sunken town, called 'Yorkshire's Atlantis', was earlier believed to be at the bottom of the sea. But a new search using sonar equipment has revealed rocks and stoneworks closer to the water's surface.
data.title: UK town 'swallowed up' by sea discovered after over 650 years, say scientists

data.author: Sakshita Khosla
data.content: Hundreds of dead Korora penguins or little blue penguins have been washing ashore on New Zealand beaches in recent weeks. Experts believe that the birds, which are the world's smallest penguins, have been starving to death as a result of global warming. The dead birds were reportedly half their normal weight and had no fat or muscle tissue on them.
data.title: Hundreds of dead little blue penguins wash up on New Zealand's beaches

data.author: Hiral Goyal
data.content: Google Cloud employee Emma Haruka Iwao has calculated the value of pi to its 100-trillionth digit, which is zero, in a new world record. Three years ago, Iwao had calculated 31.4 trillion digits of pi, setting a world record at the time. This record was broken by Swiss scientists last year, when they calculated another 31.4 trillion digits of pi.
data.title: Google employee calculates value of pi to 100 tn digits in a new world record

data.author: Daisy Mowke
data.content: Astronomers have detected a radio signal coming from a galaxy believed to be nearly 3 billion light-years away. A new paper, published in Nature journal, notes that the source of the new Fast Radio Burst is "co-located with a compact, persistent radio source and associated with...a dwarf host galaxy". It was spotted in 2019 by the telescope in China's Guizhou.
data.title: Radio signal coming from another galaxy detected by scientists

data.author: Daisy Mowke
data.content: NASA's Perseverance Mars rover captured an image of a shiny piece of foil. It's part of a thermal blanket that may have come from descent stage of the rocket that landed the rover. Calling it "unexpected", NASA tweeted that the rover descended 2 km away so the question that remains is whether the foil got blown away in the wind.
data.title: Pic shows 'shiny foil' piece found on Mars, NASA calls it 'unexpected'

data.author: Apaar Sharma
data.content: WHO chief Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus on Wednesday said that over 1,000 monkeypox cases have been reported from 29 countries where the disease is not endemic, with no deaths reported so far in these countries. The US' Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has released a list of 29 countries with confirmed monkeypox and orthopoxvirus cases till June 8.
data.title: Over 1,000 monkeypox cases reported in 29 countries; list released

data.author: Ankush Verma
data.content: Researchers believe they have discovered the origins of the bubonic plague, also known as Black Death pandemic, more than 600 years after it killed tens of millions in Europe, Asia and north Africa. The team of researchers traced the bubonic plague's origins to Kyrgyzstan. A research team from Scotland and Germany analysed ancient DNA samples from the teeth of skeletons.
data.title: Origins of Black Death pandemic which killed tens of millions discovered after 600 yrs

data.author: Anmol Sharma
data.content: Astronomers have discovered what they term to be the fastest-growing black hole ever spotted in space. The new black hole consumes the equivalent of one Earth each second, as per astronomers. The discovery was made by astronomers from the Australian National University (ANU), who describe it as a "very large, unexpected needle in the haystack".
data.title: Fastest growing black hole discovered, consumes equivalent of 1 Earth each second

data.author: Daisy Mowke
data.content: NASA will host a media teleconference at 1 pm EDT (10:30 pm IST) on Thursday to discuss a new team it is commissioning to examine unidentified aerial phenomena (UAPs). This comes after years of speculation about events in the sky that cannot be identified as aircraft or known natural phenomena. "There's no evidence UAPs are extra-terrestrial in origin," NASA stated.
data.title: NASA to launch study into unexplained aerial phenomena

data.author: Daisy Mowke
data.content: The June full moon, Strawberry Moon, will appear from around 5:22 pm in the skies above India on Tuesday. The name was given to the full Moon by the Algonquin Native American tribe in northeastern US and eastern Canada. It refers to the region's strawberry harvesting season. On Tuesday, it will come within 3,57,657 km of Earth.
data.title: What is Strawberry Moon that will rise in the skies tonight?

data.author: Anmol Sharma
data.content: NASA's Mars Perseverance rover acquired a new image using its Right Mastcam-Z camera. In the image, a rock resembling a snake head can be seen. The image also shows a round rock that appears to be balancing on a larger rock. Perseverance is currently exploring a river delta region in the Jezero Crater.
data.title: 'Snake-head' rock spotted on Mars in new image released by NASA

data.author: Sakshita Khosla
data.content: Delhi University researchers have found an unusual fossilised egg of a titanosaurid dinosaur in Madhya Pradesh's Dhar district, pictures of which have been released in the Scientific Reports journal. This is the first time scientists have come across the "abnormal" and rare 'egg-within-an-egg' or 'ovum-in-ovo' phenomenon in dinosaurs. It's been known to occur only in birds until now.
data.title: 'Abnormal' dinosaur egg fossil discovered in MP, pics released

data.author: Daisy Mowke
data.content: A star is ending its life so violently that the dead star left behind, called a white dwarf, is disrupting an entire planetary system. Astronomers have observed a white dwarf star consuming both rocky-metallic and icy material, the ingredients of planets, for first time. The findings are based on analysing material captured by the atmosphere of  white dwarf star G238-44.
data.title: Dead star caught ripping up planetary system

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: Older adults who start experiencing bad dreams can hint at the earliest signs of Parkinson's disease, a study stated. Researchers analysed 3,818 older men with typical brain functioning for 12 years and found people who experienced frequent nightmares were two times more likely to develop Parkinson's. Early diagnosis can help prevent symptoms like tremors, stiffness and slowness, researchers said.
data.title: Frequent nightmares could be early sign of Parkinson's disease: Study

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: Researchers have developed a biodegradable gel made of amino acid chains called peptides that can repair damage caused due to heart attack. This gel can be safely injected into heart and act as a scaffold for cells to grow new tissue. It's liquid under stress as peptides disassemble and after being injected, the peptides work to reassemble, making it solid.
data.title: Researchers develop gel that can repair damage after heart attack

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: Researchers have discovered fossils of a giant crocodile-faced, meat-eating dinosaur on the Isle of Wight thought to be the biggest dinosaur known in Europe. The 33-foot-long carnivore that lived around 125 million years ago could move quickly and had razor-sharp claws and rows of pointy teeth to munch anything it hunted down. Scientists have nicknamed it as White Rock spinosaurid.
data.title: Europe's biggest meat-eating dinosaur discovered on the Isle of Wight

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: Researchers have found that Zophobas morio, the larvae of darkling beetle, known as 'superworms' can survive on a diet of polystyrene. They are believed to digest the plastic through gut enzymes. According to researcher Dr Chris Rinke, these 'superworms' are like mini recycling plants that shred polystyrene with their mouth and feed it to the bacteria in their gut.
data.title: Plastic eating 'superworms' could revolutionise recycling: Study

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: Astronaut Samantha Cristoforetti posted a video on Twitter showcasing aurora dancing on the horizon of the Earth. Sharing what makes the atmosphere glow, Cristoforetti wrote that electrically charged particles from the sun collide with air molecules to cause the aurora. A Twitter user while appreciating the clip commented, "It is so beautiful," another user wrote, "Wonderful! Thank you."
data.title: Astronaut shares video showcasing aurora on Earth's horizon

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: A booster dose of COVID-19 vaccine Covaxin enhances its efficacy against Delta variant and Omicron variants namely, BA.1.1 and BA.2, a study stated. "In vaccine efficacy study against the Omicron variants...lesser virus shedding, lung viral load and lung disease severity were observed," the paper stated. Reduction in lung viral load and lung lesions were observed in Delta variant, it added.
data.title: Covaxin booster dose enhances efficacy against Delta, Omicron variants: Study

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: As per research published in the journal The Lancet Planetary Health, climate crisis has led to an increase in violence towards women, girls and sexual and gender minorities. Climate change-induced socioeconomic instability, structural power inequalities, breakdowns in safety and law enforcement etc could lead to an increase in gender-based violence across the world, scientists said.
data.title: Climate crisis may lead to more violence towards women: Study

data.author: Medhaa Gupta
data.content: A memorandum of understanding (MoU) has been signed between Ladakh's administration, LAHDC Leh and Indian Institute of Astrophysics (IIA) to set up India's first Dark Sky Reserve at Hanle's Changthang Wildlife Sanctuary. "[It'll] preserve the pristine dark skies of Hanle for science," IIA tweeted. Moreover, Ladakh Lieutenant Governor said that the site will contribute to the economy of the locals.
data.title: MoU signed to set up India's first Dark Sky Reserve in Ladakh

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: WHO on Thursday said there's no conclusive evidence to confirm the lab leak theory of SARS-CoV-2 yet. "Wuhan strain of SARS-CoV-2 has animal origin...the genetically related viruses are beta coronaviruses found in Rhinolophus bats in China and Laos," Dr Raman Gangakhedkar said. "We don't know anything about...the intermediate host - from bats to where before transmitting to humans," he added.
data.title: No conclusive evidence yet on SARS-CoV-2 origin: WHO

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: Scientists have developed a screening process that combines information about pattern of retina's blood vessels with genetic data to predict the risk of coronary artery disease (CAD) and its potentially fatal outcome, myocardial infarction, commonly known as a heart attack in an individual. Scientists say processes could also be developed to predict diseases like diabetic retinopathy and stroke.
data.title: Scientists develop screening process to predict heart attack risk from eye test

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: Chinese scientists have found signs of water in samples retrieved from a lava plain on the Moon. They found evidence of water in the form of hydroxyl encased in a crystalline mineral known as apatite in the remnants of solidified lava. These samples were retrieved by an uncrewed Chinese mission from the Moon's plain known as the Ocean of Storms.
data.title: China finds signs of water on Moon
